down to who is fighting whom the
opposition which spends as much of its

Assad's government breaks down to four
overall groups the Free Syrian Army
al-qaeda inspired rebels Islamist groups
and Kurdish fighters the most well-known
rebel group is the loose-knit Free
Syrian Army known as the FSA composed
mostly of civilians and army defectors
it also includes some Islamists its
units are increasingly autonomous not
listening to the leadership and focusing
on their individual pockets of territory
increasingly the fragmented FSA is being
eclipsed by more influential rebel
groups including radical Islamists
inspired by Al Qaeda there are two main
al Qaeda inspired groups one is
officially blessed by Al Qaeda's central
leadership and another was recently
rejected by them motivated by calls to
jihad they enjoy a steady stream of
foreign fighters arms and cash from
outsiders and in recent months they've
begun openly fighting with non jihadist
rebel groups such as the FSA a third
player in this ongoing war are the
largely homegrown Syrian Islamist
brigades including the powerful Islamic
Front these Islamists reject both al
Qaeda inspired groups and the leadership
of the Free Syrian Army and compete with
them over territory and influence there
are also Kurdish fighters they are
primarily interested in defending their
communities and would like to establish
an autonomous area like the one in Iraqi
Kurdistan in
here's how it breaks down geographically
the government controls most of the
